Dated: the словое́рс (slovojers). An obsolete honorific suffix derived from сударь (súdarʹ, sir) previously used to emphasize one’s politeness or lower social position.

Устаревшее: словое́рс. Вышедший из употребления суффикс для выражения почтения с собеседнику, исходно образованный от слова “сударь” и использовавшийся для подчеркивания вежливости или низшей социальной позиции говорящего.

sound stylistic device
Горных, речных и болотных полиций Бродят с проверкой ботинок посты.

The police move through the train cars inspecting passengers’ soles to match them to those of a suspect. This scene recalls Cinderella’s story. This reference could be to the episode in which Ilya and his companion steal a pair of boots from the hospital they ran away from (just a single pair, since both have only one leg each). Shoe motif.

register/style
Федот

Theodotus. Although incidentally mentioned at the end of chapter 2 through the allusion to a folkloric rhyme against hiccups (R163/E25), toward the end of the novel, Krylobyl, Ilya’s “spiritual” guide, is addressed by the poet in Note XXX (R206/E266), by the narrator in chapter 16 (R275/E220), and by Ilya in chapter 17 as “Fedot Fyodorov” (R279/E227). The now dated name Fedot (or Fedoty, Theodotus) derives from the Greek and means “given by God (or Gods).” His patronymic (“son of Fyodor”) stresses this divine connection, as Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.”

register/style

Ya3. ABAB.

Я3. ABAB.

metrical pattern rhyme
Эпитафии Быдогощенского погоста

This poem consists of a series of epitaphs, or short statements on the deceased, for a number of characters from the novel. The implication, of course, is that on one level all these characters are and have been dead. This poem recalls Edgar Lee Masters’s Spoon River Anthology (1915), a collection of poems that tells the stories of a large collection of fictional characters through their epitaphs. Read it here.

intratextuality intertextuality explanatory
Быдогощенского

As Sokolov explains, there is no relation between this location and the Polish town of Bydgoszcz (personal communication, June 7, 2023). It is rather a misspelling of the village (and lake) of Vidogoshch by the Volga River, near Tver’. D.B. Johnson suggests that, while the living dwell in Gorodnishche, Bydogoshch is home for the dead (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 209).

explanatory

Low: while, at the same time.

register/style
Петр По прозвищу Багор, Его все звали Федор, А он себя — Егор

Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Egor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

character religion intratextuality foreign
Багор

Pike pole — used to pull or attach objects.

explanatory
Но спорщик был и вор, На краденой на слеге Повесился на спор

The hunters’ dare to Yegor/Fyodor/Pyotr to hang himself after his time with the Dame appears in chapter 8 (R207/E100–101) and chapter 10 (R222/E127–128).

intratextuality
На краденой на

Doubled preposition for emphasis.

language explanatory
спор. Кто спорил

Figura etymologica.

Этимологическая фигура речи.

sound stylistic device
перевозчик Павел

Foma Pogibel’ is one of the two oarsmen who carry people (dead or alive) across the river (a variation of the Charon Greek myth). The other oarsman is Eryoma (diminutive of Eremei, Jeremiah). However, in Note XXXI the oarsman is called Pavel, just like the character who sends his uncle Pyotr to get yeast in Gorodnishche. As underlined by one of the epigraphs in Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools, the biblical name of Pavel is somehow interchangeable: “Saul, who is called Paul” (see Acts 13:9–10). As for Foma, he carries a biblical name, too (Thomas), whose Aramaic origin suggests the idea of the “twin.” This apostle is famous as “Doubting Thomas” due to his denial of the resurrection of Jesus, according to the Gospel of John (see John 20:24–31). In the Orthodox tradition, the Sunday following Easter is called “Thomas Sunday”: the day when Christ appeared to his disciples; it took seeing Jesus’ body for Thomas to name him “My Lord and my God.” Foma Pogibel’’s “portrait” appears in Note XXIII (R231–232/E142–143).

горба

Humpback. The image of humpbacked people and animals appears several times throughout the novel (R152, 168, 180, 184, 187, 189, 200, 217, 103, 268/E6, 61, 66, 69, 89, 208).

intratextuality
Иван

Ivan/Vanya/Vanechka. This is the name of the male nurse at the hospital where Ilya is treated (R183/E59). However, another Ivan, a “glass man” who chokes to death, appears in the Note XXXI (R268–269/E209). The name Ivan (John) has Hebrew origins and means “God is gracious.” In the Christian tradition, it is linked with the figures of John the Apostle and John the Baptist.

intratextuality
гуляка

Colloquial: someone who likes to party, relax, drink. The frequent use of variations on the verb gulyat’ is linked to the fact that, in chapter 10, Orina is defined as gulyaschaya: “была у нас Оря гулена, а стала гулящая” (R220/E124). In her case, “гулена” means “party person,” and “гулящая” is used to describe a woman with chaotic romantic relationships. Alcohol theme.

register/style theme
осокоря

Black poplar. According to Ernest and Johanna Lehner, the “black poplar tree (Populas nigra) was consecrated in Greek antiquity to Hercules, who according to mythological legend, wore a crown of its foliage when he descended to the Gates of Hades to bring Cerberus up to earth in his 12th labor. The fable has it that the black poplar leaf is a different shade on each side for this reason: when Hercules donned his crown of poplar leaves the sweat of his brow moistened one side of the leaves and they retained their natural color. But the other side, exposed to the smoke and vapor of the infernal regions he visited were tinged by the dark shade which they still retain today” (76). Here, the black poplar is likely used to set a gloomy mood in as the characters’ deaths are described, but the connection to the underworld is appropriate given Gury’s role in the novel as Ilya’s guide between the living and the dead. Plant motif.

motif intertextuality folklore
Гурий

Gury is one of the hunters living by the river. His death is described in detail in chapter 14: during an ice race, “a few verstas before the turn, Gury began gainin and the whipper-in fallin behind, but Gury aimed slightly more to the right than he should and fell into a polynya, an ice hole in the area of the fairway. […] he plopped in and right away got sucked under the ice.” Since his body cannot be found until spring, his funeral is organized “without his factual presence” (R260/E196). This episode is already briefly alluded to in chapter 1: “He was the one that adored scrapin and rollin over the slick on his sharps, which additionally resulted in us losin a client, and the undertakers, in contrast, findin one” (R150/E3).

character intratextuality
берданку

A Berdan rifle. Invented by Hiram Berdan in 1868 and used by the Russian army from 1870 to 1891 and for sport. Mentioned in several poems (R197, 202, 264, 269/E86, 93, 202, 209).

intratextuality explanatory
помер

Colloquial: to die.

register/style
помер от горя

Previously, Ilya reported that Gury drowned in a race with the whipper-in (R260/E196).

intratextuality
Коле

Diminutive form of Nikolay. Nikolay Ugodnik (Helperov in Boguslawski’s translation) is sometimes addressed with the diminutive Kolya. He is the protagonist of Note XVIII, “Transfiguration of Nikolay Helperov.” Here he is described in this manner: “We are pilgrims—he’s one far above us all, / We are cripples—he’s one far above the rest.” At the end of the Note, after a night of heavy drinking, Nikolay is transfigured (he has died): “Kolya learned to fly! / Crutches—like a pair of wings he bore. / He had turned into a falcon, poor old guy. / Drank too much. And he simply was no more.” (R204–205/E96). His life as “sincere loser in this world” is actually told by Ilya in chapter 1: his wife “got together with a wolf slayer and chased the Helper away from the house”; then, he tried to find a place to stay in Gorodnishche but was refused refuge at the “shelter for the unhearin”; he finally finds a place at the “house of the transient homeless,” but soon the “dame” notices him and asks: “Who’s the one so unsightly over there among you at the rink? Not to worry; it’s just Nikolka here among us skatin at the rink.” She asks the almshouse’s tenants to not let him live there forever, and after he leaves the house, it is reported that “durin a drunken incident got slightly upset and vanished somewhere, and it’s rather unlikely he’ll return” (R1501–151/E3–4). However, there is a second Nikolay in the book (appearing already in chapter 1), a young man from the village of Ploski (thus he is also called “Nikolay Ploskovsky”) who “never had his own name or, more precisely, had, but too long ago. And when that Nikolay the Helper went thru his transfiguration and flew away, this one snatched his name for himself—he did not allow, as they say, the goods to get wasted” (R153/E8). The name Nikolay (Nicholas) comes from the Greek words for “victory” and “people.” According to Eastern Orthodoxy, Nikolay Ugodnik (or Nikolay Chudotvorets, the Wonderworker) is Saint Nicholas, bishop of Myra (also known as Saint Nicholas of Bari), patron saint of travelers (sailors, merchants), prisoners, orphans and children in general, and others. Saint Nicholas is profoundly venerated by Russian Orthodoxy, and his life is often interpreted as concretizing various key ideas (wandering or continuous motion as source of salvation and purity; a mix of “otherness” and belonging). The figure of Saint Nicholas has served as the basis for a number of folkloric legends in Eastern Slavic tradition, and one of the most popular tales describes Nicholas as a wanderer across the Russian lands testing people for generosity, piety, and hospitality (see also T. Tsivian’s article “Nikolai Ugodnik — strannik na Russkoi zemle” 59).

character intratextuality intertextuality religion folklore

metrical pattern rhyme
Эклога

A short pastoral poem often featuring a dialogue between shepherds. Alexander Pushkin mentions the genre in his novel-in-verse Eugene Onegin in chapter 3 stanza 2. Elena Kravchenko describes the poem’s technique as follows: “The technique of the ‘Eclogue’ draws on the parodic tradition of cento, a verse composition made up of famous lines selected from the works of the past. A collage of voices, disposed in a new form or order, cento functions as parodic defamiliarization, refracting the intentions of originals. In the ‘Eclogue’ it is achieved through the juxtaposition of ‘polar’ opposites such as Khlebnikov and Turgenev, whose discourses produce the most improbable dialogue, and through the superimposition of the sign onto the alleged referent. This principle is captured in the poem’s title, ‘Eclogue’. The genre of the eclogue suggests a poem written in a classical style on a pastoral subject. Trans-contextualizing a classical verse into his novel, Sokolov creates a comic clash between the poem’s claims at bucolic bliss and the novel’s setting that starkly communicates a picture of the post-war devastation of provincial Russia. As has been noted, in its evocation of the pastoral, Sokolov’s poem is not a parody of the classical genre per se, but of the endeavour to compare artistic discourse about reality with reality itself. Moreover, it is not a simple parody of the truth-searching, but a parody of a parody: Iakov’s undertaking to compare the discourse of cultural ‘authorities’ with the real world is conceptualized through the evocation of his ‘precursors’, Don Quixote and Emma Bovary” (The Prose 58).

Эклога

A short pastoral poem often featuring a dialogue between shepherds.

explanatory
Эклога Слагалась сама. Бормоча, Достигнул поленовской риги, К саврасовской роще свернул И там, как в тургеневской книге, Аксаковских уток вспугнул

Elena Kravchenko suggests that these lines can be read as “a loose ‘paraphrase’” of chapter 4, stanza 35 from Alexander Pushkin’s novel-in-verse Evgenii Onegin (The Prose 57). Read the original here and an English translation here. Olga Matich writes: “If the realists Turgenev, Aksakov, and abovementioned painters represented reality, Khlebnikov transforms it by means of futurist discourse. Sokolov, in turn, may be said to transform it into metaliterature, which is self-reflexive in relation to both language and writing more generally. […] To summarize, “Eclogue” represents a parodic cluster whose intertexts are both obvious and implied that require interpretation and knowledge of Russian literary history, including the inscription of archaic forms (“svoiasi”), all of which are prominent in the novel. Significantly, the poem references the ubiquitous wolf – here as a visual metaphor of a wolf fang resembling a young moon – as well as a dog.We may also claim that “Eclogue” is Sokolov’s parodic pastiche of his own novel” (“Between Dog and Wolf” 256).

The house-museum estate of Vasily Polenov (1844–1927), one of the Wanderers, a group of Russian realist painters. Located on the Oka river, near Tula.

Elena Kravchenko writes, “Ivan Turgenev wrote a highly laudatory critical review of Aksakov’s book, which was later published as part of Turgenev’s Collection of Works. Thus the last two lines of the quatrain can be taken quite literally as Aksakov’s ducks indeed constitute an element of Turgenev’s book” (The Prose 57).

intertextuality

A reference to Ivan Turgenev’s 1852 cycle of short stories Notes of a Hunter (also translated as A Sportsman’s Notebook, The Hunting Sketches, and Sketches from a Hunter’s Album). This work was acclaimed for its portrayal of peasant life.

language
Плясавших

Dancing. This word is crucial to Sokolov’s art. Chorea — a movement disorder belonging to the dyskinesias group of neurological disorders. Its name comes from the Ancient Greek “χορεία” and was used to described the movements of those inflicted by the disease. Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools, is dedicated to Vita Pliaskina, which refers to Sydenham’s chorea (also known as “St. Vitus’s dance, пляска святого Вита in Russian). Watch a video here. Referred to several times in the novel (R171, 191, 205, 214, 215/E37, 74, 97, 113, 115).

Bayan — a chromatic button accordion from Russia. It was developed in the early twentieth century and named after Boyan, a bard from The Lay of Igor’s Campaign, an epic Old Russian poem.

волка веселого клык. Привет вам

Аллитерация (в, л).

sound stylistic device
свояси

Colloquial: haunts. Typically used in the expression “вернуться во свояси” (to return to one’s homeland). Leona Toker writes: “without mentioning the word ‘return’ the apostrophic penultimate line implies that the speaker has turned rather than re-turned, to his native region, earlier familiar to him only from literature and art. This is, or ought to be, his birthplace, or rather the birthplace of the language whose natural vitality he reclaims from oblivion” (“Gamesman’s Sketches” 354–365). Elena Kravchenko reads this word as an allusion to Velimir Khlebnikov’s 1919 article of the same name (The Prose 57). Read the original here.

русский язык

A possible reference to Turgenev’s famous “prose poem” Russky iazyk (Russian Language). Read the original and an English translation here. However, Sokolov affirms that “if there is any allusion here, it is not to a specific writer, but to the Russian language as a whole, with all its authors and ordinary speakers” (personal communication, August 4, 2023).

Возможная отсылка к знаменитому стихотворению в прозе Тургенева Русский язык. Текст можно читать здесь. Однако, Соколов утверждает, что “если тут есть какая-то аллюзия, то она не на кого-либо из литераторов, а на весь русский язык в целом, со всеми его сочинителями и рядовыми носителями” (личная переписка, 4 августа 2023).

Стрелецкая

Sagittarius — an astrological sign and the constellation Sagittarius. November 22–December 21. In chapter 1 (R150/E3), “streletskie chisla” are mentioned, suggesting the time period (November-December). According to Greek mythology, the centaur Chiron mentored Achilles in archery. Gerald Smith reads this poem as a “requiem for the backwoods life on the Volga written from the point of view of an exile or emigre, who compares emigration with death and who is nostalgic for what he has left behind” (“The Verse” 331). Constellation-heavens motif.

Скорпионом

Scorpio — astrological sign and constellation. October 23 to November 21. According to Greek mythology, Orion, the great hunter, sought to kill all animals, so the goddess Gaia ordered Scorpio, a giant scorpion, to kill him. motif
Паклин

A last name given to Orina in chapter 12 (R246/169). Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

phraseologism
с

Dated: the словое́рс (slovojers). An obsolete honorific suffix derived from сударь (súdarʹ, sir) previously used to emphasize one’s politeness or lower social position.

Устаревшее: словое́рс. Вышедший из употребления суффикс для выражения почтения с собеседнику, исходно образованный от слова “сударь” и использовавшийся для подчеркивания вежливости или низшей социальной позиции говорящего.

Сумерками ослеплен

Between dog and wolf. “Blinded” in the sense that it’s difficult to make out what is before one’s eyes during twilight. The entire Note allegorically plays on one’s inability to discern a maple from a tatar maple, similar in their signifier and signified.
